summary: From the largest elephant to the smallest shrew, the city of Zootopia is a mammal metropolis where various animals live and thrive. When Judy Hopps (Ginnifer Goodwin) becomes the first rabbit to join the police force, she quickly learns how tough it is to enforce the law. Determined to prove herself, Judy jumps at the opportunity to solve a mysterious case. Unfortunately, that means working with Nick Wilde (Jason Bateman), a wily fox who makes her job even harder.

As someone who has been an enormous Disney fan all my life (the only films that don't do much for me are 'Chicken Little', 'Home on the Range' and 'The Black Cauldron', if it counts also 'Planes'), Zootropolis may not be as good as the best of classic Disney or the 'big four' of the Renaissance era.

However, it is for me the jewel of Disney's 'second renaissance' (their return to form era starting with 'The Princess and the Frog', and if it counts -might not as it is Disney Toon Studios- their only misfire from that era is 'Planes'). Despite a couple of issues 'The Princess and the Frog' was still enormously entertaining. 'Tangled was Disney's best since 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame' (not sure how much of a popular opinion that is though), until the even better 'Wreck it Ralph' took that title. 'Winnie the Pooh' was immensely charming and sweet with its one problem being that it was too short. 'Frozen' despite what people say to me was the best animated film of 2013 besides 'Ernest et Celestine' (and the amount of hate it gets and the detractors' attitude towards those who loved, or even liked, the film has been blown way out of proportion). And 'Big Hero 6' was fun and touching with one of Disney's most endearing characters in recent years in Baymax.

Onto the review properly for 'Zootropolis' now. The animation is fantastic with rich colours, vivid, beautifully designed and colourful backgrounds and lovingly designed characters whose movements flow fluidly and never robotically. Some of it is even very inventive and imaginative in the set pieces. Michael Giacchino's score is cleverly orchestrated, energetic and catchy, not as good as his scores for the ones for the Pixar films 'Up' and 'Inside Out' but it complements 'Zootropolis' very well indeed.

'Zootropolis' has some very smart and hilarious writing, cleverly balancing sly references, witty humour and also genuine pathos and heart with few if any awkward tonal shifts. The visual gags are similarly inventive and a joy to watch. The story is so consistently well paced and involving and is told with such energy, charm and heart that some may forget the storyline being predictable. To me, it had enough originality to not make it matter that much. What was also impressive about 'Zootropolis' was how it dealt with such heavy and wholly relevant themes and issues, one of most daring along with 'The Hunchback of Notre Dame' and deal with it with a light touch. Some did find the message (one that's easy to identify with) forced and heavy-handed, it wasn't an issue to me at all, to this viewer it was incorporated well and respectfully.

The characters in 'Zootropolis' are interesting - all serving a point to the story- with colourful personalities, none of them felt bland, none felt shoe-horned in, none felt annoying and none felt unnecessary. Love the sassiness and charm of the protagonist, and while the twist wasn't a surprise as such the villain did serve a good threat and more interesting than the recent Disney twist villains. The voice acting is just terrific from all, especially from Ginnifer Goodwin and Jason Bateman. Can't go wrong with Idris Elba, JK Simmons and Maurice LaMarche either.

All in all, with the one small exception of the forgettable and slightly grating main song from Shakira (which was not enough to bring the film down personally) 'Zootropolis' was a superb film, not only of Disney's post-2009 films but also one of their best post-Tarzan and towards the top end in the Disney animated film ranking. 10/10 Bethany Cox

This animated comedy was really good. Ginnifer Goodwin, Jason Bateman, Idris Elba, Jenny Slate, Shakira, and the rest of the cast did a fantastic job on this movie. The plot of the movie was entertaining, humorous, and thrilling. It's about fighting for something you've always wanted and doing what's right to bring the true criminals to justice. If you haven't seen this animated movie yet, check it out sometime. It's a great movie for an entire family.

My 14 year old daughter just had me watch this for our family movie night and it was fantastic! 
Judy Hopps, first ever bunny cop, heads to the big city of Zootopia. Will it eat her alive?
Witty, with a couple of great messages that don't beat you over the head. Fab voice acting, stunning artwork and just all around great entertainment.

A nice story that is fittingly concerned with nature and individuality. It has a nice message and tackles some chancy themes in a very mature way which could easily have been inappropriate if handled wrong. The world is colorful and beautifully animated, and how everything works has a lot of nice creativity behind it. The movie is also very funny, and the humor is also taking advantage of the unique setting.

Even if it often leaves you excited for the next plot point, overall it comes off as wonky. The jokes aren't really that funny outside of "sloth is slow get it" while the commentary about introducing crack cocaine to Black neighborhoods comes across as weird when you realize the predator/prey dynamic is literally separate species, uncomfortable at best for a racial comment.

This story has a lot of messages about police brutality and racism. The main character herself seems to be a metaphor for a racist cop learning the truth about her society. Judy Hopps and Nick Wilde have become very well known amongst Disney fans. The music is pretty cool, the world building excellent and the characters are fun. Nick Wilde's growth is similar to Eugene in which it shows a person who does bad things change their ways. I wouldn't say this movie is exactly life changing and it's definitely not the best anti racism story you can show to your kids. It's more of a movie that would be enjoyed by animal lovers in general.
Absolutely the best animated film of all time.

In a large city populated by mammals of every sort, a bunny cop must team up with a street hustling fox to solve a missing mammal case. What makes this movie shine is the writing. Creating an allegory for racism between predators and prey works extremely well. The different boroughs of Zootopia to accommodate animals from different environments is creative. Jason Bateman and Ginnifer Goodwin work well together and the supportive cast is memorable in their own ways. This film is well put together, a new gem in Disney animation and a must watch.

This type of world building with character driven story is something you'd expect from Pixar at their brilliant best, but Zootropolis is Disney Animation's doing. The story itself is progressive in its outlook, a female bunny achieves her dream of becoming the first rabbit to become a police officer, but faces prejudice in every aspect of the job. Zootropolis has an excellent message at its heart, but it's also cleverly written and amusing, perfect to keep the kids (and adults) occupied during this summer holiday afternoon.
Has a brilliant tomato score and critics but wow, I found it really a chore to get through. It was not for me. Character designs not for me. Just seemed a bit boring actually.

Summary: Judy Hopps dreams of leaving Bunnyburrow and becoming Zootopia's first rabbit police officer. Her first day on the job, she gets stuck with parking duty and gets duped by a sly fox. She hopes that one day she'll be able to fight real crime.

Takeaways: In a world where prey and predators live harmoniously (well, mostly), the animal society still has stereotypes about the jobs each animal is meant for. A precious story about following your dreams with a spunky main character and many laugh-out-loud moments.

Saw this opening weekend at Disney world with mr young nephews holds a special place in my heart. The story was fun well executed. Characters were memorable had depth and weight their back stories fed well into present circumstances. And that song is a total ear worm.

By far my favourite Disney movie

Thanks to Disney+ and an unlimited number of Disney movies at my fingertips, I was finally able to enjoy Zootopia last night. It was surprisingly a very adult-centric movie and for a while I even forgot I was watching a Disney cartoon. The animals portrayed had very emotional, real world human problems to overcome and guaranteed anyone who watched this movie can relate to one of them. Personally...I relate to the sloths. But on a more serious note, I am very pleased to have found out that a sequel will be released later in 2021 because these characters are just too good to be one and done then forgotten about.
Zootopia is a utopia of imagination, every scene filled a flurry of cleverness and cuteness.

This review contains spoilers.
Zootopia is one of the most loved animated films of recent years and considered by many to be a masterpiece. I am included among them.
I've seen it at least 5 times, but each time it remains a perfectly aimed film.
The animations are spectacular and from 10 and praise: the hairs are treated in detail and the areas of the city are memorable.
Even in the characters sector we only have iconic characters: Nick is my favorite, well characterized and with a poignant background. Judy is a great protagonist and with a beautiful story arc.
The sheep is a nice twist villain that the first time I wouldn't have bet a cent on her, and good motivation too.
The story is deeply inspired, unpredictable and manages to entertain.
The jokes are genuine and very funny.
Zootopia is a great film that makes perfection its philosophy: there is nothing negative to mention and I'm really trying to find something!
With photorealistic animations, fantastic script and well-made characters, Zootopia is a must see.

Probably one of the greatest movies Disney has ever made. There is something about Zootopia that makes me genuinely happy. Every time I sit down to re-watch this movie, I cannot help but get one fat smile on my face. My serotonin levels go through the roof whenever I watch the movie. Make no mistake, I LOVE this movie. This movie has everything I could ever want out of an animated feature. Intriguing story that keeps you invested all through out. The characters themselves are extremely fun and loveable. The main protagonist, Judy Hopps, is the type of person you would want to be friends with no matter what. Overall 10 outta 10, undeniably kino.
So much fun to watch for all ages! I love love this movie!
Great show. So original. The voice actors did an incredible job.

An interesting take on real life problems. From prejudices and stereotypes to disabilities and acceptance. A fresh insight. It's a brilliant film for all ages. There's so much to reflect and learn from. Also, a great look at relationships and how people relate to one another. With lita of humour and goregous animation, Zootropolis is a definite classic.
Excellent movie, that touches social issues, 5 stars

Funny and a amazing concept.
I really didn't want to watch this movie but my sister still managed to force me to... I'm glad she was so persistent!

Watching this a few years after it came out and seeing all the accolades and warm reception it received makes it seem pretty clear that it was overrated upon release due to the political climate of early 2016. The story is indeed well-told and the animation is extremely good, far outstripping Moana from 8 months later, but the voice acting is only good, not great, there are no songs to be had and there's nothing to really latch onto as a favorite or memorable thing from the movie as they put a ton of effort into being well-rounded. There's a modicum of comedy, a dose of mystery and an underdog component but no facet of the movie is fantastic. I'm glad that I watched this as I'd heard of characters from the movie outside of it, but it's an otherwise-unmemorable police procedural with a rather plaudit-seeking morality angle.
A great animated movie

A work of art produced by Disney that told the story of a young bunny who fought against all the odds to become a well respected police officer while unknowingly making a sly fox once a con artist into a best friend for life. In Zootopia there is no limits to what you can be, your biological species doesn't define your destiny. This made it even more enjoyable watching a struggling main character persevering through the hardship. It's nicely structured story coupled with hilarious scenes made the movie even more so enjoyable.
Wonderful anti-racism movie for young and old, with a great detective plot

This movie was released at a perfect time when people are judging each other by what's on the outside instead of realizing that we are all the same. There are no undertones as it is thrown in our face but in a digestible way, even kids can understand. The main character Judy even has to let go of the prejudice that she has grown up with her entire life. it is really a beautiful movie to watch. The only reason that I am taking half a star off is because of the time period and how they chose to focus on her career as a cop. Cops are so glorified nowadays that we always see them as just individuals even though the system is corrupt. Besides that amazing movie!
Another fun, fast-paced Disney flick.

The Best Film Of The Year, So Far.
From the studio that brought you Tangled, Wreck-It Ralph, Frozen & Big Hero 6, Zootopia surfaces as a highly original, incredibly refreshing, thoroughly engaging, surprisingly timely & delightfully subversive beast fable about prejudice & stereotype that not only marks a new creative high for Disney but is arguably the finest film that this legendary animation studio has come up with in their Revival Era, so far.

Set in a world inhabited by anthropomorphic animals, the story of Zootopia takes place in the titular metropolis and follows a bunny cop named Judy Hopps who, despite her par excellent performance in the class, is assigned parking duty by her superior. But when she volunteers to undertake a missing-predator case, she is given 48 hours to solve the mystery or resign, following which she blackmails a sly fox into helping her, and uncovers a sinister conspiracy.

Co-directed by Byron Howard & Rich Moore, the duo put up an intriguing world on the screen that does have a fresh quality but there is still a deep sense of familiarity to it. However, where the two leave a lasting impression is in finding that perfect balance between its consistently gripping storyline & moments of pure hilarity. The writing staff also deserves a mention, for their screenplay brims with numerous pop culture references, parodies many renowned classics & handles its topical themes with care.

The 3D animation is absolutely top-notch, for the images retain its crispness, clarity & vibrancy from beginning to end. The animators put up a vast number of characters on the screen, ranging from the largest elephant to the smallest shrew, yet they are all given a well-defined arc. Cinematography further enhances the overall look n feel of the story with its fluid camera-work, splendid use of colour palette & spot-on lighting. Editing provides just enough screen time to all the relevant characters while moving the plot forward at a blistering pace.

The cast is wisely chosen, and all the actors do a competent job in lending their voice & soul to the mammals they play. Ginnifer Goodwin brings a bubbly side to the new cop in town and confidently plays her role. Jason Bateman plays his part with finesse plus his voice really fits his cynical con artist character. Also, the chemistry between the two is a highlight in itself. Michael Giacchino's ebullient score seamlessly blends in & compliments the narrative while Shakira beautifully wraps everything up with a catchy, uplifting & wonderful song that smartly summarises its themes & message.

On an overall scale, Zootopia finds Disney stepping out of its comfort zone to tackle a bold, ambitious & risky project, and it is one gamble that pays off tremendously well in the studio's favour. Also, its arrival couldn't have been better, considering how its elements of prejudice & stereotypes mirror the racial hostilities present in our very own current social environment. An ingenious blend of sophisticated storytelling, jubilant humour & thought-provoking themes that amazes, entertains & enlightens without ever compromising with the fun factor, Zootopia is a definite delight for viewers of all ages, and is undoubtedly the best film of the year, so far. Strongly recommended.
